job_title: Merchandising Execution Associate in Loveland, CO
pros: The Home Depot has a solid moral compass. They aren't about sacrificing their ethics for the sake of a sale, which I love. They also hire a diverse group of people and give a lot back to the community. They offer a lot of benefits and little treats for their employees. Although they push their associates to meet quota, they're realistic about what can and can't be accomplished.
cons: Home Depot has two different sides to it. Store associates and those of us considered "store support" who are payed by the vendors but work in the stores 100% of the time. I constantly hear about how store associates are stressed out by management and their hours are being rearranged a lot, cut, and they often are stretched thin due to lack of full staffing. "Store support" associates who do merchandising have it better than those who work in specific departments. However, you never really gain knowledge unless you have the time to look things up and read packaging.

review_title: False promises. Great if you like a hamster wheel.
job_title: Exterior Design Consultant in Wheat Ridge, CO
pros: When I first started, we were straight commission, and made great money. You used your own gas and your own vehicle but we’re paid very well. They changed pay plans and gave us a company car and a small salary plus “bonuses” it was a massive cut.
cons: Management couldn’t care less about you. You’re not judged by what you have done or achieved. It is “what have you done for me this month.” Go from making $110k+/yr on commission with the flexibility of setting your own schedule and no expectations of work if you aren’t on the appointment schedule. They changed the plan to $40k/yr plus bonuses and you get a company car. They promise promotions but find any excuse to not bump you up. Including the birth of my child which made me miss 3 weeks of January making me short on my “goals” which made them put me on a “coaching plan” which meant no promotion I sold more than I did when I made the 110k/yr on commission and only made 75k after bonuses on the new plan. While being expected to be in the store or in appointments for 55+hrs a week. When the leads dried up, you were expected to “self -gen” your own leads and if you fell short, you attend a punitive meeting at 7am an hour away to “learn how to self gen”. They took a great program and job and ruined it.

job_title: Customer Service Associate in Kennesaw, GA
pros: From day one you start off with benefits that are reasonably priced for the economy, and you also are provided a week of vacation after I believe 6 months of working there.
cons: The management is horrible. Our manager didn't even have phone experience from working at The Home Depot and was hired from an outside job to manage the customer service agents on the phone with no experience of our calls and handling our calls and taking calls for The Home Depot in general. The shifts are looong. To get a great shift your stats have to be at 100% for months and years at a time. The great bonus they talk so highly about is not great at all and taxes take most of it even if you are exempt. The customers overall only shop at The Home Depot because they know they can scam the company completely. They always are going to get a refund and they yell and complain all day. None of your calls are nice, none of your calls are pleasant people calling to order items off line.. every call is a problem with the delivery or installation company and they will not take the calls from customers and are the main people disrespecting the customers and we are the front line. Pay is horrible and there are no raises but always adding more responsibility to the job duties.

pros: They offer a lot of benefits, such as PTO and affordable insurance.
cons: Once there is a company-wide increase in pay, be prepared to have to fight for a fair raise. I was there for 2-3 years when the most recent one occurred and everyone was bumped to the same pay as someone who had just started the same job. Not fair to employees who know a lot more/have more experience, and on top of that, have to train those new employees. I had to move stores to get a better raise. Also your satisfaction at your job depends on management. Some work their way up to be an ASM or SM just to sit in the office all day and not help you out whatsoever. It is incredibly frustrating. Some of the managers can be on a power trip as well.

Some orders consist of large lumber orders that need to be picked, banded, wrapped and staged for either delivery or pickup. review_title: Poor pay compared to executive salaries
job_title: Part Time Sales Associate in Bridgeport, CT
pros: Benefits for part time associates Flexible schedule for part time
cons: Have worked over ten years part time at the Home Depot. I earn $17.50 per hour - now Home Depot is advertising starting part time sales positions at $17.00. I earn $.50 per hour more than someone who just walked in the door. I can operate every machine in the store but get no extra pay for that major responsibility. The executive staff take home $millions while some of my colleagues rely on food banks. I'm fortunate that I have a full time job as well. The Home Depot talks a good game about caring about its associates but the truth is it's all about putting bonuses in the executives pockets and keeping major shareholders happy.

pros: Most co-workers are great. Insurance is decent. Customers are great.
cons: Managers are like a club. Occurances (points against you) for things like calling in sick, or making mistakes you didn't know you made result in a "coaching" which isn't coaching, but a script they read to you stating that too many occurances may lead to termination. That you are at Home Depot to work it's important to show up. They also ask for a heads up so they can plan. Usually can't plan when you get sick.

job_title: Hardware Associate in American Fork, UT
pros: It really keeps you in shape. I love teaching customers how to do their projects and which tools are right for the job. Customer engagement is tops and I constantly hear them say how much they enjoy our store. They advance from within and if you hang in and do well you will advance up the ladder along with pay. I love our GM, ASMS, DS and especially our HR person. If you have a family or personal issue they are 100% supportive. The employees become good friends. Safety is #1 and you are never required to do anything that is unsafe. You have vacation time from day 1 and you have flexibility in your schedule. It is a great place to work.
cons: Theft from the store is crazy and shrink effects our yearly bonus. I just wish they'd place a loss prevention person at all exits as they do at Costco Other than that thought, I can't think of a con.

review_title: Job was totally different than advertised and not in a good way
job_title: Pro Desk Sales Associate in Taunton, MA
pros: I worked at the Pro Desk at Home depot in Taunton, MA. The other people I worked with were vey nice and likable associates.
cons: The store was chronically understaffed. Floor sales associates were hired and fired on an ongoing basis. Sometimes they did not last even a day. This resulted in the pro desk employees being plugged in wherever the store was short of help, doing everyone else job who was fired or did not show-up that day, which in turn prevented us from getting our objectives met at the Pro Desk, very unhappy contractors. After 3 months of chaos I gave my notice and happily moved on.

pros: I can see this being a good thing in the sense they’re look out for their company, employees, and customers.
cons: I think one should be hired or not hired on a person by person basis. I have 8 years in recovery, and with my addiction came along with getting in trouble with the law. However, since I’ve been clean I’ve done so much to make up to society. I was on the wall in the probation office for being a positive role model, they actually had a plaque on the wall for me to inspire others. I did a 6 month documentary showing the life of a girl leaving jail and trying to get her life together, this was a 6 month project where they started filming me in jail. This documentary was for the public to understand. I volunteer at animal shelters. I studied and got licensed in Peer Recovery Support, to help others struggling in a place I used to be in, and to show them the way out. I’m still doing good, but it’s harder to find a job, it seems ppl only see the bad I’ve done, but none of the good. This is one of the companies that loved me until they got my background back, and that job that I was so excited about was gone. Again I do understand the thinking behind the policy of companies not hiring ppl w backgrounds, but we need to better as a community. That’s just my piece.

job_title: Sales Associate in Palm Coast, FL
pros: Excellent training in all departments. Your choice of hours and days off are entirely up to you. Supervisors are very helpful in your initial training. Most fellow Associates are amicable and willing to help you if they are not otherwise occupied.
cons: You will work 6 or more hours in a department with no other Associates to assist you. A department with 5 to 6 aisles and only one Associate will cause extreme frustration as you cannot satisfy the customers' demands in a timely manner. Depending on the demographics of your store, you may encounter customers that are very demanding, impatient, rude, and sometimes insulting. You will need to have a great deal of patience to survive in this environment. Don't plan on being able to take any breaks other than a mandatory lunch break. Don't count on finding a fellow Associate to partner with when you need assistance because they will be stretched just as thin in their department as you are in yours.

review_title: Merchandising is a different beast from store side, which is good and bad
pros: If you finish ahead of your schedule on completing bays/projects, chance to go home early. If you are part-time and this gig is normally Monday-Friday on a set schedule, you get more choice on what you want to work. 3 8-hour days instead of 5 5-hour days? Cool. Off on Mondays and Fridays and work Tuesday-Thursday? Great. If you have a good supervisor, then it's great. You work with the same people everyday, same time, and can get some awesome work relationships this way.
cons: Waking up at 4 or 5am, depending if you start at 5am or 6am. Been doing this almost 10-years and it hasn't gotten any easier Part-time is usually 20-25 hours but some stores allow them to be 32 hours so if you are a 32-hour part timer, don't take it for granted. Working with the same people everyday, at the same time. It can be a pro and a con if you don't get along with someone that you'll be seeing almost as much as a family member. Gotta wear ugly orange shirts. Canadian merchandising team gets to wear gray with orange 😭 You are basically timed in everything you do. Projects we complete have a predetermined time it should take, etc. Basically if you worked 8 hours, the powers that be want their technology (work phone) to track each thing you do and the time it took and make sure it equals out to 8 hours at the end of the day as we are required to scan a barcode that signals us starting a certain task. Time management has to be good. Some stores are horrible but some are more lenient.. the lenient stores that don't meet their metrics get yelled at and probably won't be a manager forever.

job_title: Software Engineer II in Atlanta, GA
pros: None really. There's free food around the building sometimes if you get there before the other two dozen people going for it
cons: Most toxic place I have ever worked. First off, their main metric for productivity on my team was "butts in seats". So no matter how much work you got done, you were expected to be in your seat from 9 am sharp, until 6:30pm, with an hour lunch that better not go a minute outside of 12-1. My manager once told me this was because "if my boss walks through and sees that nobody is here, they'll think no work is getting done." Other teams at THD measure productivity by Lines of Code, widely regarded as the stupidest possible productivity metric for software development. As expected, this results in really bad, intentionally drawn-out code. Management also uses gaslighting and fear to keep employees in check. At the time I got hired by THD, they were rebranding their corporate imagine and saying they were now a "silicon valley tech company". This was because they had garnered a reputation around Atlanta for being a developer sweat shop and treating their corporate employees terribly. The rebranding was a lie. They were still the same company. A couple months into my tenure at THD, they laid off ALL of their contractors (hundreds, most of whom were recently hired and many of whom were on visas and had to leave the country because of the sudden layoffs), because they didn't meet their earnings goals, EVEN THOUGH they plainly said this was due to inclement weather that year, and they had made more money that year than they ever had previously. They did it with a clear message of "work hard or you might be next". The team that I was on was half local and half in another city. The team in the other city seemed to think that if they didn't "beat us" then they might get cut (a mentality that was, no doubt, handed down by the awful, toxic management at THD, that you will find all throughout the company at the corporate level). This created an environment of ANTI-collaboration. Teammates would actually withhold information privately, and then share it demeaning-ly in meetings, holding up development for the sake of looking like the better employee. We even had meetings that exploded into name-calling between the two teams. Everyone I know who still works for this company is miserable and trying to get out. I got out as fast as I could. I've worked at a handful of places. Some decent, some great. But THD is the only place I've worked that I would call TOXIC, and I still can't believe how terrible and childish the culture was. I would not recommend working here to my worst enemy.

job_title: Tool Rental Associate in Raleigh, NC
pros: -I have worked at home depot for roughly 7 years in various departments while making my way through college to graduate debt free. pros: Job stability: Home Depot is a well-established company, which can provide job stability for head cashiers. Opportunities for advancement: Being a head cashier can be a stepping stone to higher-level positions within the company. Customer interaction: Head cashiers have the opportunity to interact with customers, which can be rewarding for those who enjoy helping others. Variety of responsibilities: Head cashiers have a variety of responsibilities, including managing other cashiers, handling customer complaints, and balancing the cash registers. This can make the job interesting and challenging.
cons: High stress environment: Head cashiers are responsible for overseeing a busy and fast-paced environment, which can be stressful at times. Long hours: Home Depot stores are typically open for extended hours, including weekends and holidays, which may require head cashiers to work during those times. Physical demands: Standing for extended periods of time, handling heavy equipment, and repetitive motions can be physically demanding for head cashiers. High pressure: Head cashiers are responsible for ensuring that transactions are processed accurately and efficiently, which can be stressful and high pressure.

pros: - Solid benefits, even for part-timers. Ie free vision plan, Employee Stock Purchase Plan. - Regular career advancement coaching for associates. - Some associates are extremely kind & helpful to newcomers.
cons: - You can get reprimanded for both insufficient documentation & excessive documentation in the same week, & sometimes by the same manager. - Store management has little capacity to push back against nonsensical mandates from corporate. - No employee discount on inventory, even culled lumber. - Out of date, slow order management software (much of it goes back to the 1990s). I spend as much time waiting for the order software to work as I do actually working. - Company says it's "green" but trashes tons of stuff it could recycle. - Company gives tacit & financial approval to antivaxxers & other conspiracy theorists both internally & externally. - District/store management ignores cheap/easy suggestions for improved store safety/hygiene, particularly in restrooms - Full-time employees are often cliquish & will close ranks against part-time ones in disputes with customers, vendors, or corporate. - Company prefers to work with a small number of large subcontractors for administrative convenience, rather than the reverse, regardless of customer satisfaction. - When something goes wrong & you get pulled into an office to talk about it, it's always "your problem," never a problem with company policy or a toxic relationship that other employees have with you. - There's a principle & a procedure for everything when dealing with subcontractors & customers with no exceptions, except that there are exceptions, & you're expected to know those exceptions without being told about them, & oh yes you're going to get lectured to on them in front of your coworkers. - Part-time associate hours can change on a weekly basis, depending on a computer algorithm.

job_title: General Warehouse Associate in Ontario, CA
pros: Compensation-wise, base pay is solid. Adjustments (pay increases) happen every few years. The latest one was over $2 and change, in order to “remain competitive” (I’ve experience 2 adjustments in the 6 years I’ve worked there). Yearly raises depend on performance, but can be up to $1 in some cases. There is company “success sharing” every quarter (if the building hits eligibility requirements). These are different for everyone as it depends on hours worked, but can easily be a few hundred extra every quarter if you do your normal 40 hrs (more if you worked overtime). Obviously there are other companies that pay a little more for starting (I.e. U-Line) but may be more difficult to get into without experience. Culture-wise, Home Depot imo exceeds expectations. They really emphasize caring for the associate in general. They also encourage involvement and engagement via events/games/rec rooms. I’m not really big on these myself, but the avenue it provides for associates helps make the environment more comfortable — remember this is mostly a labor intensive job, and Home Depot does well to help alleviate the fatigue that it comes with. They promote a concept of “family” and “bleeding orange” and “living the 8 core values” which can help with a sense of belonging, for those who care (others prefer to mind their own business — totally fine). Those other reviews that bash on this as a “cultist” thing over the company cheer are over-reacting. It’s there but participation is 100% voluntary; I’ve never done one myself (you can say ”No” people…) As far as benefits go, Home Depot provides a solid spectrum (tuition reimbursement, Kaiser for health insurance, etc). I myself didn’t learn it’s true value until they were lost (I moved on). On a related note, one of my favorite things Home Depot does is their Homer Fund — a program designed to help associates in need due to extenuating circumstances (death, natural disaster, etc.). It’s funded by associates, then matched by the company. Overall it’s a good variety. Career-wise, let me preface this by saying that politics are Everywhere — no matter what job or industry, there will always be the favorites/unfavorites game and you will always be faced with unfair disadvantages. That said, the opportunity Home Depot proves is incredible if you can navigate yourself to those open doors. So go in and kick butt and you will be training on heavy equipment and other functions in 3-6 months and possibly promoted with another 12 months. I’ve seen people come in and get supervisor role in 1.5 years. There are people who have had an opportunity to join the support roles (Auditing, Asset Protection, Transportation, etc). Some have even gone into Corporate or Engineering fields. The opportunity is definitely there, and while the playing field is never fully fair to everyone, hard work does go a long way. Anyways, I’ve said a lot, and while this company isn’t perfect, Home Depot strikes a great balance. You can either complain about its negatives or chose to be more positive or open minded about the opportunity. *Also, the extra day(s) off you get with the 4/10 and 3/12 shifts is INCREDIBLE. Having gone to a 5/8 was a rude awakening for me. I cherished my days off the most.
cons: Politics, Favoritism, “Fake/Two-faced” individuals, etc. (that stuff is everywhere) Also, buy some comfortable shoes, the concrete floor really does a number on your feet.

The entire AMP Dept. awards more internal Homer Awards than I've seen from entire C-Level Suites. There's a whole lot of "patting themselves on the back" mentality happening.

Different skills to learn include, customer service, inventory and cycle counts, shipping and receiving, stocking, warehouse management, and operating lift equipment.
cons: High attrition rates. Much of the highly skilled and tenured workforce has left Home Depot. HR is now trending in hiring less skilled and younger talent, because they are cheaper labor. But you get what you pay for. The values that Home Depot prides itself on are in decline as a result of not willing to take care of the more skilled and tenured staff. It is difficult to keep morale high when you are constantly training new staff like a revolving door.

review_title: Great Corporation to Work for but with High Expectations
job_title: Operations Assistant Store Manager in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: + Company leaders live and expects others to live their values (which include respect, diversity and inclusion, giving back). + Company expectations are high for all levels. Home Improvement sales isn't an easy industry to work for but you will learn more and quicker there than any other big box retail by a wide margin. + THD leaders are sought after. I've personally been head hunted several times from hiring managers in the industry and outside. + Benefits are good for the industry. A lot of options for medical (HMO, EPO, PPO) and they offer many services for free (Vision, Teledoc, CareSolutons4Life). + Employee Stock Purchase Program is available for a discount 2x/year.
cons: - Doesn't pay enough based on their goals and expectations. Should consistently lead in this field not just try to keep up. - Vacation accrual by service year is not as good as others. 1 year = 1 week, 2 years = 2 weeks, 5 years = 3 weeks, 15 years = 4 weeks. Other retailers give another week per 5 years. Europe is far ahead on this. Why aren't we better!? - Bring back HR managers to lead a company standard training program. Company rely's too much on computer/phone training and not enough on ensuring associates are doing (how many people learn). They expect all Managers to be HR managers. Great in theory, causes far too many issues in reality (not everyone knows HR SOP well, communication can be poor between ASDS and Management team, everyone thinks the ASDS IS the HR Manager, etc.). - It's a large corporation so networking and politics are a skill you must master to move up successfully and quickly.

pros: There are a lot of great things about working at Home Depot. I believe it is a very good first job to obtain after high school and gives you a lot of perspective about how work life is and can be.
cons: Some of the negative experiences I have had with Home Depot would be the managers, sick hours, and hours available per week. It may be understandable that for every 30 hours you work you get 1 hour of sick time, but for there to be incidents where you do not accumulate enough hours for when you are actually sick so you can still receive an occurrence and be placed on probation. I believe this is not acceptable due to the fact that no one can predict how many times you can get sick in a year especially due to COVID-19 which can result in the managers having a negative reaction to you calling out. There are also times were you will be scheduled 8-14 hours for 1 week. This was a very difficult 2 months that I had to face from August to September which had caused me to get a second job.

pros: I didn't know anything regarding millwork when first starting. Was a challenge but got up to speed with some online classes that were mandatory (but only really covered a quarter of what the job requires.) I did learn a great amount of home DIY and repair, process of how contractors build estimates, timeframes/turn around time for projects and more as well as also dealing with difficult situations with frustrated clients and vendors. I learned some other departments over time but stayed in Millwork, had opportunities to go to others but our dept was always understaffed and was told I needed to wait till they hired someone to replace my position before going to a new role. That was more attributed to my role as a specialist but saw many co-workers move into new roles pretty quickly which is a plus.
cons: Our store only had 3 other people that could confidently configure and process special orders. ASM's were often brought in to deal with customer issues but didn't know anything about the process of special orders or how to use any of the software. They would promise customers things out of our control and wouldn't set the proper expectations creating even more stress. This on top of managing and stocking everyday retail inventory, lack of coverage, refusal to hire other staff despite customer and contractor complaints were all factors in resigning. This was only my dept, Millwork, so possibly smoother experience in other departments but realize this is still grounded in retail. Even though most of it was trail by fire, the learning experience I gained was immense.

The job itself was fine, boring and tedious by fine. Although there are productivity standards, as long as you're not a total idiot nobody messes with you and you can pretty much work at your own pace. We had the usual crotchety older co-workers, but don't let them get you down. Avoid the breakroom sometimes so you don't have to hear their gossipy nonsense and you'll probably be smooth sailing. I did make some good friends there though and would say its worth a try if you have any sort of interest in merchandising or home goods/repair.
cons: Pay is kinda crappy, I was shocked the lifers didn't make much more than me for their hourly wage. Theft is rampant and I was annoyed the store doesn't seem to do much to prevent it, but I guess that wasn't my business - I just worked there.

review_title: A good reliable job but hard to grow
pros: I have worked a steady job in more or less the same position as a part timer and full timer for the last few years as a student and graduate. The job is full of many friendly faces, good meaning and well talented fellow associates so it makes it feel very safe and reliable. Especially recommended for students and anyone in need of benefits as they offer a lot of decent benefits to their employees like tuition reimbursement, part and full time health benefits among others.
cons: There are a lot of internal politics that can make it challenging to grow, and long term may not be the best thing as your main interest. It can be very repetitive and sometimes feels like your voice can get ignored if you aren't close to the inner circle of people in charge at that time. Lots of redundant and needless decisions that waste time instead of making logical decisions to increase efficiency and quality of life, with simple things like marking stock locations, or seeing favouritism often being a large reason for promotion over actual work history and work ethic.

review_title: Mismanaged, Chaotic at times, lots of theft.
pros: The only pro to this job is that compared to every other department, the service desk has the least work to do and get to handle the least amount of customers (not by much). Either that or if you are in or fresh out of high school this job is decent for the time being until you find something better, and if you are in that position, DO IT AS SOON AS YOU CAN.
cons: Training is tons of short "interactive" videos that go on and on. There is so much content you most likely aren't going be able to finish it all (let alone remember half of it) until a few months later like most people do. Instead you'll get sent to the sales floor and learn from there through your peers (who they themselves don't always know every bit and procedure of their job since they were in the same boat as you when they started and some still learning different things months later). Outside of the Service Desk most departments work like this as well. Not only that you end up learning things in these videos that don't even pertain to your department or job description, which is why I say you will probably end up forgetting half of the info from these videos because of how painfully non-engaging, long and sometimes irrelevant to what you would actually be doing in store (depending on your department of course). This make the job incredibly frustrating because you will be semi-regularly critiqued by management and look like a moron in-front of customers to no fault of your own. Otherwise it's tolerable for a bit until you find something better, given the area the customers you get are a mixed bag. Some very fine folk and others, straight up degenerate scum bags (blatantly obvious drug addicts, thieves etc). It's not uncommon where customers come in to either steal or return merchandise they took from the store for one of Home Depots "Store Credit" cards so that they could probably buy whatever using the credit with basically free money (probably to flip it later or just for keeps). And of course like any retail store there will be "karen" types who come in complaining about their return not going through even though they don't have a receipt of any kind (this is the most manageable but time consuming part of the job), they will argue and argue not to get store credit. Although sometimes its not totally their fault since at the checkout, cashiers may scan something twice or miss-input something into the register. Resulting in us being forced to take their word for it and pushing a return through anyway despite them having two of one item on a receipt and they only have one of that item, and another of a similar item (this usually happens after having to get a manager or supervisor so you can C.Y.A.). All of this would be manageable if the people who worked here were payed more. As of writing this I started at $14.50, and only got a raise when minimum wage was bumped, now I am at $15.50 roughly. Your hours are messed with constantly and the times you work are far from consistent, rather erratic in fact. Either HR or corporate do not know how to manage hours correctly or are being intentionally stingy when it comes to pay (which especially sucks since were are in a real recession, our wages are the same but everything drains your wallet). It is most likely why turnover rate is so high for the store compared to other Home Depots (let alone in general) and is constantly understaffed. If I had a couple of dollars for every time a customer asked for assistance in a aisle or department when no one was there, id make enough to rival my current wages. TL;DR if you have better options. DO NOT WORK HERE, you will find yourself regretting it pretty quickly.

job_title: Customer Service in Chula Vista, CA
pros: We’ll let’s start with the good parts. There are great benefits and the pay is decent. We got payed biweekly and hours where plenty. About a handful of employees where great to be around
cons:
There are a lot of hours and many part-time employees where scheduled full time shifts without regard to their personal lives. Many students left due to this problem, myself included. Our hours where not changed no matter how much we asked. Management was disorganized, as they where constantly trying their best to put out fires that where caused by lack of knowledge on their end. 

Getting licensed to work on the equipment is a hassle as there are only a few trainers. Almost every manager can train you to use equipment such as forklifts but won’t take any time out their day to do so.

There where a few horrible managers and supervisors that would have no regard for their employees safety and require them to quickly complete tasks that required two people.

Actually, many departments only have a single person. The order fulfillment department had it the worst as it was always one person working a job that required at least three people.

pros:
All of this is subjective and only applies to what I have experienced. 

-Good leadership.
-Plenty of acknowledgment (praise for just doing your job and more so for going above and beyond). 
-You learn more at smaller Home Depots with Plenty of room for growth -Internally promoting.
-Great benefits and plenty of resources available to associates 
-Apparently, you can climb the ladder as high as possible without a college degree but it doesn't hurt to take advantage of their college resources.
 -Harass your leadership if need be to learn all that you need to learn about the store or the resources available to you because there's A LOT. 

*Be wary of negative reviews. Yes, I'm sure there are legit and reasonable concerns but be wary nonetheless. Everyone handles everything differently.*
cons: I've had only one complaint about my management but it's been fixed now due to a new person joining management. It was extremely shameful and almost downright unforgivable but peace has been restored, for now. So now, no cons, it takes something serious to be a con for me. One more thing, I often hear that larger Home Depots struggle with good management, overall morale, and guidance/training. Anyone that's switched to our store has always mentioned something along those lines. Just try to be positive, do your job, and grow. Take care of number one because no one else will. Moreover, become the change you want to see in Home Depot, what I've mentioned previously about a new person in management that changed what was going on in our store. Become strong and good enough to be able to change a store for the better. It's called "doing the right thing"...wow, who'd've thought...

job_title: Part Time Sales Associate in Phoenix, AZ
pros:
The application process is fast and easy to complete. 
Basic customer service skills are all that's needed to begin the job and do well overall. 
Plenty of self-driven training is available if you want to learn your or other department related skills and activities. 
Coworkers are typically easy to get along with. 
Management's availability is very high and multiple assistant managers are typically in the store at the same time.
cons:
Promotion potential, even for someone far more skilled/credentialed than the job requires, is low. 
Promotions seem to be politically motivated in some stores (managers have favorites, promotions are not based on departmental competence, etc.).
Base pay is improving, however they still do not provide a livable wage, especially for part-time workers. 
Scheduling strongly favors the needs of the company over employee needs and preferences. This can be very challenging in special circumstances or for full- or part-time students.

job_title: Staff Software Support Engineer in Austin, TX
pros:
- teamwork isn't just a buzzword here
- most IT workers have freedom to work remotely from almost anywhere in US
- decent profit sharing and stock grants for senior individual contributor roles
- very diverse workforce, and they're not bothered if you're over 40 unlike many technology firms (yes, with thousands of developers Home Depot *is* a technology firm as well as one of the world's largest retailers)
- management usually walks the talk
cons:
- it's retail, so expect to work hard so customers can get what they need now
- pretty pitiful PTO, 2 weeks until 5 years, don't get a 4th until 15, only six paid holidays annually (see: it's retail)
- health benefits are pricey and not terribly comprehensive
- over-reliance on contractors and pricey talent from other firms (Ernst and Young is everywhere in the Security organization) and stubborn refusal to staff support roles
- you'll always have more work than you can complete

review_title: Leading Retailer; Flexible Hours; Great Benefits; Hard-working Employees
pros: Most employees are hard-working DIYers. As a part-time employee, I get to set my own availability and create a flexible work schedule up to 32 hours per week. I usually work 21-25 hours per week. Lots of opportunity to demonstrate work ethic and get recognized for one's efforts. Pay is consistent across role and experience. Top performers are frequently recognized, but not paid any different.
cons: Stores tolerate huge amount of theft and shoplifting. Full-time employees have much less flexibility, and most work at least one weekend day. All jobs require stamina as most of the day one is standing, moving, lifting or talking to customers. Work is fulfilling but can be very exhausting. Easy for low performers to coast and still retail job. Hard to get fired, unless caught stealing from the store or violating asset protection protocols (following suspected shoplifters out of store).

review_title: Nice place to work, if you can handle the bouncing ball of times to work
pros: I enjoyed helping customers. Many were not familiar with the tools in the Hardware Department and it was fun showing them how they worked, what different tools did and the tasks they could perform for the customer.
cons: I hated the schedule. I tried to talk to my manager but it never went anywhere. I worked part-time being retired and it was a nightmare, getting up at 5AM, to be off work at noon, then back in at 5PM to work until close. Also I had only worked there two weeks and they had me working alone in a large sized department, with no one to call to ask questions when problems arose, except the assistant store manager and he was always busy putting out fires in other departments. I hurt myself and couldn't stand being on my knees trying to put stock away is why I quit, but the main reason was the rollercoaster hours. Part time is 20 hours not 32!!
